courses.title: Understanding China through Cultural Landscape
courses.description:
(UGEA1212 is double-coded with GRMD1003.)

This course aims to introduce China’s cultural heritages from the perspective of cultural geography. As an important sub-discipline in human geography, cultural geography examines how people use space and develop it into places – a process of cultural landscape formation. “Space” here is nothing immutable or monolithic; instead, individuals, groups, civilizations and their culture “craft” characteristic places through interactions with the surrounding environment and specific political and economic systems (themselves determined by culture). China provides numerous extraordinary examples to illustrate these topics. The course includes four key components: 1) the theoretical foundation: fundamentals of cultural geography; 2) the legacies and regional variations of China’s cultural heritages; 3) topical issues about China’s cultural heritages; 4) the cultural convergence in aspects of globalization and cultural transformation. The course provides not only a body of knowledge about the cultural landscape and spatial variations of places in China, but also an understanding of their major transformations that have taken place in a globalizing world.

courses.learning_outcomes:
| Students are expected to develop a general and comprehensive understanding of China’s cultural heritages, using the approach of cultural geography. Broad issues regarding China’s cultural heritages will be discussed to appreciate that cultural landscape formation is the result of multiple forces (e.g. natural, geographical, social, economic, political, etc) working together to form space and then places. After completing the course, students will be able to: * adopt a normative stance in evaluating the cultural landscapes; * identify essential features of China’s cultural heritages from the lens of cultural geography; * understand Chinese cultural heritages’ multiple dimensions and geographical variations, and how these factors shape and reinforce space, place and cultural formation; * discover cases or use experiences to describe and diagnose how the development of Chinese cultural heritages is associated with forces at different geographical scales such as local, regional, national and even global scales; * organize their ideas and information under the framework of cultural geography; and * explain their ideas in a communicative manner to promote Chinese culture. |

courses.course_syllabus:
As shown below, the course contents will be divided into 4 parts and 12 topics.

Part I: Fundamental of Cultural Geography: Interpreting Places and Spaces of Cultural Heritages (3 lectures):

This component covers key theories and concepts developed over the past 30 years in cultural geography (both classical and new cultural geography approaches), and explain why cultural geography offers a very unique but important approach to study China’s cultural heritages. Theoretical exploration will help bring out ideas about space, place, power, cultural landscape, and identity. How people use space and develop it into place will be discussed. Many examples will be used to help students understand the approaches of cultural geography.

1. Introduction: cultural geography as an approach

文化地理方法导读

2. Culture, space, place and power

文化、空間、地方與權力

3. Shaping of China’s cultural landscape: traditions, foreign imports, and globalization

中国文化景觀的形成：傳統、外來影響與全球化

Part II: Cultural Heritages and Regional Variations (5 lectures)

In the first three weeks, the course has laid the theoretical foundation. Now, student will begin their journey of understanding the subject matter, with a focus on several key cultural regions in China. The aim of this component is to covey a deep sense of place as an integral system engaging multiple force, e.g. myth and legend, power and politics, history and tradition, religion and symbol, nature and geography, cultural practices, and society’s interconnection with the environment. Students will make a good sense of a wide geographical variation of Chinese cultural values and practices.

4. Beijing: Beijing Culture and the place of politics

北京：京派文化與空間的政治

5. Shanghai: Shanghai Culture and the place for spatial competition

上海：海派文化與空間的爭奪

6. Southwest: Ethnic culture and the place of ethnicity

西南：民族文化與鄉土空間

7. Tibet: Religious culture and the place of belief

西藏：宗教文化與信仰空間

8. Lingnan: Lingnan culture and the place of diversity

嶺南：嶺南文化與多元空間

Part III: China’s Cultural Imprints and Dynamics: Topical Issues (3 lectures)

The aim of this component is to let students further appreciate the diversified studies of cultural geography by introducing several topical issues.

9. Ancient villages: A place of spatial representation

古村落的空間意象

10. The cultures of production and workspace

生産的文化與勞動場所

11. Graffiti: the cultural geography of Youth in China

塗鴉：青年文化地理

Part IV: Cultural Convergence and Transformation (Globalization) (1 lecture)

Globalization is an unescapable trend, and this powerful trend has greatly impacted on China’s cultural heritages. The cultural convergence and transformation will be discussed. The focus is not simply to interpret convergence as some kind of loss of unique characteristics of our cultural tradition. Rather, we wish to stress that when one gets involved in intercultural interaction, one should be likely to become aware of and even enhance one’s cultural tradition. Problems and local responses in cultural heritage conservation in China will be explored.

12. China’s cultural heritage under globalization: a cultural geography perspective

全球化下的中国文化遺產: 文化地理學的解讀

(UGEA1310 is double-coded with FAAS1600.)

In light of artifacts whether excavated or collected as well as historical texts, this course provides an overview of Chinese art over 5000 years. Through studying the art and culture of the pre-historic era and the Bronze Age, and the development of painting, calligraphy, religious sculpture, architecture, jade, gold, silver, and ceramics throughout the centuries, students will understand the special characteristics and historical development of Chinese art and culture over the centuries. Artistic exchange between China and its neighbouring countries will be given special attention. Tutorial sessions involve practical workshop or the study of actual art objects at the Art Museum.

courses.description: This course introduces students to an understanding of the changes of the ethnic landscape in China from the past to the present. Through close readings of ethnographies, viewing of videos, and fieldtrips, this class examines various topics in multiculturalism in China, including ethnic relations, global economy, religion pluralism, and cross-cultural romance and marriage, in the context of globalization. This course also compares multiculturalism in different Chinese societies and discusses the possible futures of PRC. Over the past decade, China has been committed to advance the UN’s 2030 Sustainable Development Agenda (17 Sustainable Development Goals, SDGs). This course also discusses to what extent the development in China meets these goals, particularly in the area of sustainable economic growth, social equality, and cultural inclusiveness.

courses.course_syllabus:
The major concepts in this course include multiculturalism, globalization, and ethnicity. The core content includes:

* *Module 1: Multiculturalism in the Past**

* Chapter 1&2: Multicultural China in History*

The first two chapters review various episodes of multiculturalism in Chinese history and shows that ethnic boundaries in China are always fluid, not a fixed entity.

* *Module 2: Multiculturalism at Present**

* Chapter 3&4: Ethnic Relations (SDG10, 16)*

These two chapters discuss the current ethnic relations in urban China – it is not a simple dichotomy between Chinese and non-Chinese but interrelated with gender, race, ethnicity, class, and language.

* Chapter 5&6: Global Economy (SDG8, 10)*

These two chapters discuss the economic role of China in the global economy, particularly, its role in the high-end and low-end globalization, and how this role has transformed the urban space in China.

* Chapter 7&8: Religion Pluralism (SDG16)*

These two chapters discuss the role of the state in the regulation of religion (i.e. promoting religion pluralism in a hierarchal structure) and how non-Chinese believers comply with or circumvent these regulations.

* Chapter 9&10: Cross-cultural Romance and Marriage (SDG5)*

These two chapters discuss the opportunities and constraints configured by cross-cultural relationships in romance and marriage in China.

* *Module 3: Multiculturalism in Future (SDG8, 10, 17)**

* Chapter 11&12: Comparing Multiculturalism in Hong Kong and China*

This topic compares the discourses and practices of multiculturalism in Hong Kong and China and discusses the future development of these two places – will they become more alike or different with regard to multiculturalism?

* *Various topics in relation to multiculturalism in China, such as food, education, environment, popular culture, migration, and sports, are the selected topics for this course.**

courses.description:
(UGEA1450 is double-coded with CURE1122.)

The aim of this course is to help students understand the basic religious characteristics of Chinese culture and the relationship between religions and the daily life of Chinese people. It also helps students to appreciate the richness and diversity of the Chinese traditions and acquiring essential preparation for more advanced courses in the area of Chinese culture and religions. The course is divided under the familiar categories of Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Popular religion. These traditions are, by no means, discrete and mutually exclusive. It will be demonstrated that they overlap and interact with each other through a variety of confluences and conflicts. Students will also be introduced to some primary source of the Chinese traditions including both textual and fieldwork data.

courses.title: Reading Chinese Culture and Politics through Movies
courses.description:
(UGEA1515 is double-coded with GPAD1073.)

Since its birth in the late-19th/early-20th century, Chinese movies have provided a very rich pool of images and stories, real or fictional, through which political messages could be read, interpreted, constructed, and re-constructed. As politics is a reflection of culture, a systematic analysis of these movies will provide students with a “softer” way to understand the cultural context which shapes Chinese politics. After an introduction of the relationship between culture, movies, and politics, the course will examine how Chinese political culture could be read through Chinese movies produced under different political settings (Republican, Maoist, and post-Maoist China).

courses.title: China and Asia: Past and Present
courses.description: This course aims to introduce the history of interaction between China and its neighbouring states in Asia since the premodern time. This course adopts an interdisciplinary approach – including the perspectives of history, international relations, and Chinese culture – to understand China's subjective and objective position in the region. China had been regarding herself as the leader in East Asia until European Imperialism intervened in the 19th century which challenged the legitimacy of Sino-centric order. With the growing acceptance of China's resurgence, this course provides a systematic analytical framework for students to understand the contribution of such historical and cultural factors to China's foreign policymaking nowadays.

courses.description:
With increasing interest and usage of traditional, complementary and integrative medicine (TCIM) worldwide, it is recognized that public education is a key to promote safe and effective use of TCIM in the community. The World Health Organization Traditional Medicine Strategy 2014-23 has specified the strategic direction of: 1. Ensuring consumers of TCIM can make informed choices about self-health care. 2. Promoting proper use of TCIM products and services.

This course aims to serve as an education intervention for achieving these two goals. As the most important form of TCIM in China and Hong Kong is traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), this course aims to introduce the basic theory and practice of TCM to our students. In addition, it will also briefly introduce the cultural and philosophical aspects of TCM .

We aim to empower informed healthcare choices by promoting awareness on TCM diagnostic and therapeutic approaches. As a secondary aim, this course serves as an introduction to TCM, such that students from the Faculty of Medicine (e.g. western medicine, nursing, public health and pharmacy) can gain a basic understanding on TCM, preparing them for future interprofessional learning and practice of integrative medicine.

courses.description: As an important component of Chinese culture, Chinese music not only functions as entertainment, it also reflects the political situation and the social vicissitudes of China. In order to include multiple perspectives on viewing Chinese cultural heritage, the course is designed to provide a broad exposure to Chinese music through a wide spectrum of topics, such as basic concepts, notation, important genres and repertoire. No previous musical training is required, however, students’ understanding of Chinese musical culture will be reinforced and broadened by the end of the course. In addition, students will also understand how music serves political and social functions in ancient and contemporary China.

courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction
1. Basic concepts and terminology.

II. The evolution of Chinese music in two aspects
2. Chinese musical instruments
a. Traditional Chinese musical instruments.
b. Sinicization of foreign musical instruments from Central Asia in different period (Han, Tang, and Song dynasties) and the historical and cultural background behind it.
c. Modernization of Chinese musical instruments under Western influence after 1949 and its political background.

3. Musical notation
a. Traditional notation (*lülüpu* (律吕譜), *jianzipu* (減字譜), *gongchepu* (工尺譜)) and the underlying aesthetic.
b. Westernized cipher notation and staff notation.

III. Four major categories of Chinese music
4. Instrumental music
a. Traditional solo repertoire: *Guqin* (古琴) and its relation to the Chinese literati culture.
b. Ensemble: *Jiangnan sizhu* (江南絲竹), *Guangdong yinyue* (廣東音樂) and folk entertainment.

5. Song
The role of *Shijing* (詩經) , *Ci* songs (詞樂), and the ‘School Song Movement’ (學堂樂歌) in modern China.

6. Narrative singing
The decline of narrative singing (*Nanyin* 南音, *banyan* 板眼) and the social changes in Hong Kong (from the 1920s to the 1970s).

7. Chinese opera
The development of *Jingju* (京劇), *Yueju* (上海越劇) and *Yueju* (粤劇), and how they are affected by socio-political and economic factors.

Optional
Cultural and musical exchange
1. The influence of Chinese culture on Japan and Korea.
2. China’s reception of Western culture since the late Qing dynasty.

courses.description: Music has existed in many forms throughout Chinese history. The characteristics of each style and genre are shaped by sociocultural, geographical, and historical contexts as well as changing definitions of what it means to be Chinese. Beginning with the notion that Chineseness and Chinese culture are changeable and malleable, this course introduces students to various forms of Chinese music performed and popularized in Chinese and Chinese-speaking communities and their relationship to the construction of Chinese identity and sociality. Students will not only learn to appreciate the nature of the ever-changing world of Chinese music but to listen to it with critical insights and to understand how it relates to its context. Rather than approaching Chinese music as fixed and unchanging tradition anchored in a lineal historical trajectory, this course will treat each genre as a unique product of its time and social ethos. Hearing music in social contexts is a dynamic and productive way to enhance students’ understanding of the evolution of Chinese culture, identity, and the construction of community. The final project will be a group collaboration analyzing aspects of a genre of Chinese music found in Hong Kong. No previous musical knowledge is required.

- --Identify the unique ways that Chinese culture is being constituted through sound.
- --Comprehend the diverse characteristics of Chineseness through sonic means.
- --Describe different views on Chinese Music in terms of social and cultural values.

courses.description: The course introduces the philosophical thought of Confucianism, Taoism, and Buddhism, so as to give students a deeper understanding of the roots of Chinese values and culture. As a cornerstone of Chinese culture, Confucianism contributes to the establishment of the human moral way by articulating a conception of humans as moral subjects. courses.description:
(UGEA2180 is double-coded with ANTH2410.)

This course provides an anthropological approach to examining Chinese culture and society. Some of the key questions we raise include: What does it mean to be Chinese? What role does culture play in being Chinese, and what constitutes Chinese society? Our emphasis is on the dominant cultural practices of societies around the world that render them ‘Chinese’.

The course will also situate contemporary China historically within the world-system and examine the dramatic transformations it has undergone as a result of the post-Mao reforms beginning in the late-1970s. Because China has become the world’s most dynamic growth-engine since these reforms were launched, the Chinese experience offers itself as a case-study of the benefits as well as challenges thrown up by modern development.

Since China has committed to implementing the 2030 development agenda, including Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) such as clean water, affordable clean energy, and climate action, this course will offer students the opportunity to familiarize themselves with the discourse of sustainability as articulated by the SDGs. But more than that, with specific reference to the experience of the People’s Republic of China in particular, the course will afford students the opportunity to reflect upon the apparent contradictions existing between what is understood to be ‘development’ on the one hand and ‘sustainability’ on the other.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students should be able to:

- explain why claims about being Chinese and Chineseness can be such a source of contention.

- explain why there are similarities as well as differences across different Chinese societies.

- historically as well as anthropologically account for the place of contemporary China within the world-system.

- critically discuss the major features and social institutions of Maoist and post-Mao China.

- discuss the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), their significance in our times, and how ‘sustainability’ challenges ideas of development in general and Chinese development specifically.

- critically evaluate which of the 17 SDGs are realized – or compromised by - the Chinese development experience.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Core Content**

1. Culture and Humanity

2. What Makes One Chinese?

3. Overseas Chinese and the Different Articulations of Chineseness

4. Situating the PRC in a historical and global context

5. Vignettes of Maoist China

6. The Anthropology of Post-Reform China

7. Discussing post-reform China in light of the Sustainability Development Goals (SDGs)

What does it mean to be Chinese? What role does culture play in being Chinese? And what constitutes Chinese society? When Chinese populations elsewhere (e.g. overseas Chinese) lay claim to being Chinese, what are they invoking? On the other hand, when ethnic Chinese Hong Kongers claim that they are not Chinese, for instance, what are they implying? Is being Chinese primarily given by ethnicity, nationality, cultural/civilizational practices, some combination of the above, or all of them?

This line of questioning would suggest that when we invoke “Chinese culture and society”, we refer not only to culture and society in China but also beyond, to Chinese societies elsewhere that have emerged as a result of the Chinese diaspora. Yet at the heart of this discussion still lies the question with which we first began: what does it mean to be Chinese? And what binds mainland Chinese societies with those overseas?

Because the shared identity of being Chinese has here been shown to transcend geographical and national boundaries, I would propose that being Chinese pertains more to the evolving practices of culture than it does the more limiting constraints of ethnicity, geography, or nationality. This class therefore examines the constituents of being Chinese, with the emphasis placed on culture as its animating force.

Accordingly, we begin the course by underlining the significance of “culture” to being “human” and trace out the implications of this proposition. (Topic 1).

Indeed, it is because culture is a cumulative and evolving social phenomenon – a process - that accounts for the diversity of Chinese societies around the world (e.g. Hong Kong, Singapore, Taiwan), that there is something identifiably Chinese in each of them, yet something else that differentiates between them. A pluralist cultural view of “Chinese” - a civilizational view (?) - will thus be taken as we tease out the similarities and differences existing across these societies. (Topics 2 and 3).

After discussing the differences between the Chinese societies of the world, we will turn our attention to examining the People’s Republic of China (PRC), whose breathtaking economic development over the past forty years is not in question. Because China - and the PRC, specifically - is a political entity that has had a history of antagonistic relations with the West, the course approaches discussion of China by first problematizing it as a political and historical entity, including its Maoist-Socialist past. (Topics 4 and 5). Such historic contextualization of China is felt to be necessary, the pre-requisite for any discussion of contemporary China, not least its post-Mao developments.

This brings us to the many aspects of post-Mao and post-reform China, the last forty years that have come to be associated with China’s famed developmental experience. (Topic 6).

The consequences of Chinese development - especially in the post-Mao era - speak to most, if not all, of the SDGs, which can be understood to refer to sustainability in three realms: economic, social and ecological. Hence, the anthropology of post-reform China (6) will necessarily highlight issues pertaining, for instance, to poverty and hunger alleviation (SDG 1,2), health and well-being (SDG3), gender (SDG 5), inequality (SDG10), energy (SDG7), and urbanization (SDG 11), among others. This is conducive for a discussion about the SDGs with reference to Chinese development and an examination of whether or not, and when, they are consistent.

courses.title: Introduction to Classical History Books
courses.description: This course introduces four classical history books of ancient China: Records of the Grand Historian (Shiji), Standard History of the Han (Hanshu), Records of the Three Kingdoms (Sanguozhi) and Comprehensive Mirror for Aid in Government (Zizhi tongjian). It particularly analyses the historical contexts, purposes, genres, compilations, historical thoughts of these history books and the characteristics of the Chinese culture shown in them. Students are given close guidance to study the typical writings in these historical books to comprehend, analyse and appraise the essence of traditional Chinese historiography as well as the evolution and characteristics of history, politics, economics and society in the Chinese cultural heritage from multi-disciplinary and comparative perspectives, and reflect on the intellectual and cultural insights of these traditions into the contemporary society and life.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Not for History Majors. 
Co-requisite: UGFH1000 or UGFN1000 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students are expected to be able to identify, comprehend and critically appraise through intellectual dialogue :

1. the essential features of the traditional Chinese historiography, which is an important part of the Chinese culture;

2. evolution and characteristics of these aspects of the Chinese cultural heritage in the historical contexts;

3. intellectual and cultural insights of these traditional aspects into the modern society and life as well as their close and meaningful relevance;

Students are also expected to:

4. develop a broad historical perspective for reflecting on perennial issues and concern for various situations of human existence;

5. broaden the intellectual perspective for mastering the important ideological trends of the contemporary world and understanding issues related to their life and society, and addressing unfamiliar problems of today with the application of historical wisdom; and

6. master the ability to analyse and compare historical documents in depth and articulate the related history and its significance in writing.

同學修畢本科之後，當能通過智性的對話學會辨認，理解並批判地評鑑：

1. 作為中華文化重要部分的中國傳統史學的主要特徵；

2. 在歷史脈絡下中華文化傳承的演變及特色；

3. 傳統帶給現代社會和生活的智性的、文化的啟示，以及傳統與現代之間密切的、富意義的關聯；

4. 拓展歷史的視野，反思歷久彌新的課題，關注各種人類處境；

5. 擴展智性的視野，掌握當今世界的重要思潮，明瞭自身的人生和社會問題，運用歷史智慧處理今天的種種陌生問題；

6. 掌握深度分析和比較歷史文獻和書面表述歷史及其意義的能力。

courses.title: Understanding Chinese Constitution and Legal Culture
courses.description: This course provides an essential guide for students to acquire a basic understanding of Chinese constitution and legal culture in historical development and in the modern era. Building on the historical and comparative perspectives, this course will discuss topics related to the concepts of Chinese law, legal culture and Zhonghua Faxi, the development of China’s ancient constitution, late Qing’s constitutional reform, constitutional innovation in the Republican era, and the development of Chinese Constitution since 1949. Through lectures, readings, and exploratory projects, students will be encouraged to critically assess the interweaving legal and constitutional perspectives on the Chinese history and civilization.

courses.course_syllabus:
* *Module 1:The Legal and Cultural Foundations for the Chinese Constitutional Order: Tradition (Weeks 1–4)**

This module examines Orientalist misconceptions about Chinese law and legal culture, and explores the emergence of Chinese legal culture and system before and after the unification of China. Confucianization of law and the pursuit of an efficient de facto constitution without a written constitution had become part of the legal tradition in ancient China.

* **Week 1The Legal Orientalism Question: Explicating the Chinese Law**
* **Week 2The Origin and Main Features of Chinese Legal Culture**
* **Week 3*Zhonghua Faxi* (The Chinese Legal System): An Overview**
* **Week 4Constituting a Big State: The Constitution of Ancient China**

* *Module 2: The Evolution of Chinese Constitution in the Late Qing Period and Republican Era: Modernization (Weeks 5–6)**

This module explores three key milestones in the evolution of the Chinese constitution in the first half of the 20th century: The late Qing constitutional reform, Sun Yat-sen’s five-power constitution, and the founding of the Council of Grand Justices in 1948. These new developments represent China’s efforts to embrace a new constitutional order with a written constitution that adheres to modern standards and unique constitutional innovations inherited from traditional Chinese cultures.

* **Week 5A New Constitutional Order: Constitutional Reform in the Late Qing Period**
* **Week 6The Republican Constitutionalism: The 1946 Five-Power Constitution**

* *Module 3: The Development of Chinese Constitution since 1949: Continuity and Innovation (Weeks 7–13)**

This module explores the development of the Chinese constitution since 1949 with a focus on its continuity and innovation. While continuities with the traditions of the continental legal system and the Chinese culture can be observed, there were also noteworthy innovations arising from Chinese socialism, liberal constitutionalism, party leadership, “One Country, Two Systems” policy, global constitutionalism, efficient government, and legality. Both tradition and innovation have shaped the unique road of Chinese constitutionalism and the present Chinese constitutional order.

* **Week 7Making the Reform and Opening-up Constitution: The 1982 Constitution**
* **Week 8Constitution and Liberalism: On the Chinese Reception of American Constitutional Law**
* **Week 9Party Leadership and the Chinese Constitutional Order**
* **Week 10Weak but Efficient Court?: Judicial Powers in China**
* **Week 11NPCSC and Constitutional Review**
* **Week 12The “One Country, Two Systems” in the Evolving Chinese Constitutional Order**
* **Week 13An Outlook on Chinese Constitution and Legal Culture: Continuity and Innovation**

courses.description: The course familiarizes students with the philosophical and cultural roots of China’s foreign polices and examines critically the development and significance of China’s foreign relations in the modern period. This interdisciplinary course explores how China views the world and its changing role in world affairs, drawing from both Chinese and foreign scholarship in history, philosophy and international relations.

courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Philosophical and Cultural Underpinnings of China’s Foreign Policymaking

Week 1: Understanding the “China Playbook”

This session introduces different theoretical approaches to an understanding of China’s foreign policymaking. The rise of China as a world power has become the most significant international relations issue in today’s international order. Understanding the context and content of these debates is essential for comprehending China’s foreign relations and global role in the 21st century.

Week 2: How China Views the World (I): Historical Roots of China’s Foreign Relations

This session introduces the historical development of China’s relations with the world. It will review foreign relations of Imperial China, including early encounters with the West. It will critically evaluate the importance of historical factors in explaining China’s practices in international relations.

Week 3: How China Views the World (II): Lessons from pre-Qin Thinkers

This session examines foreign relation philosophies from the Spring, Autumn and Warring State Periods, and how pre-Qin thinkers counselled rulers on foreign relations. Relevant concepts such as authority, hegemony and the ancient Chinese concept of *tianxia* will be explicated.

Week 4: How History and Philosophy Inform Contemporary Chinese Foreign Policymaking

This session discusses how history and philosophy inform the foreign policy of contemporary China and introduces the characteristics of contemporary China’s foreign relations, with a view to understanding the elements of tradition and continuity in China’s foreign policies.

Part II: China and Major post-WWII Powers

Week 5: China-US Relations (I): Overview

This session analyzes the historical context and contemporary developments in China-US relations. It will critically examine the history of Sino-American relations since early 19th century, and investigate historical and cultural factors behind the development of Sino-American relations since 1949.

Week 6: China-US Relations (II): Current Issues

This session introduces the latest development of Sino-US relations in the global context, and discusses several key aspects of current China-US relations, including economic issues and trade, strategic competition, and areas of cooperation.

Week 7: Sino-Russian Relations after the End of the Cold War

This session explores the relationship between China and the former USSR after the end of the Cold War, and discusses the key issues in current Sino-Russian relations in the global context.

Part III: Thematic Studies: the European Union, the Belt-and-Road Initiative, and the Global South

Week 8: China-EU Relations

This session discusses the main factors impacting China’s relations with the European Union (EU). It will examine the history of political relations between China and the EU, the economic relations between the two actors, and selected current issues in China-EU relations in the global context.

Week 9: The Belt-and-Road Initiative

This session examines how China’s role in the global economy and geopolitics has evolved in the modern period, particularly in the context of the Belt-and-Road Initiative launched in 2013. It will introduce the goals and plans of China’s Belt-and-Road Initiative and discuss the pros and cons of major policy agendas under this initiative.

Week 10: China in the Global South (I)

This session introduces China’s relationship with the Global South, with a specific focus on Africa. It will examine China’s rising influence in Africa, and discuss the achievements and challenges of the evolving China-Africa relations.

Week 11: China in the Global South (II)

This session introduces China’s relationship with the Global South, with a focus on Southeast Asia, Latin America, and the Middle East. It will discuss the dynamics of these relationships and how these are impacting a host of crucial global issues, such as BRICS politics, peacekeeping, poverty reduction and the environment.

Week 12: Borders, Territory, and Neighborhood Diplomacy

This session delves into China’s relationships with its Asian neighbors, examining the complexities of border management, territorial disputes, and diplomacy. It will examine the impact of historical conflicts and legacies on contemporary Asian international relations, and introduce theoretical frameworks of geopolitics and identity politics for analyzing the major issues and challenges of international relations in the region.

Week 13: Conclusion: Contrasting Conceptions of the “China Playbook”

This concluding session discusses contrasting conceptions of the “China Playbook” and the influence of Chinese foreign relations on the world order. It will explore the viability and sustainability of the “China model” in contemporary China’s foreign relations.

courses.description: This course aims to provide a concise introduction to the rich and complex history of China, and how this historical heritage finds manifestation in the lives and thoughts of Chinese people today. Modelled upon and enriching UGCP1001 “Understanding China”, the course will focus on five themes: intellectual foundations, historical epochs, modernisation, economic development, and science and technology. It will explore the link between tradition and modernity for each theme, drawing on selected works on China from philosophy, history, sociology, economics, and science. Students will be introduced to major events, interpretations, and perspectives pertaining to China’s transformations in the past and present, and will be guided to reflect on contemporary developments in China through lectures, readings, and exploratory projects.

courses.course_syllabus:
* *Weeks 1–2 Perspectives on China**

The sessions explore the origins of the common perception of China as a unified multi-ethnic and multi-cultural socio-political entity, and anticipate the general challenges in understanding its grandeur, complexity and diversity.

Week 1

* Origins of Chinese civilisation
* Ethnic diversity in China
* Shifting borderlands of China

Week 2

* Beginnings of Chinese state and nation
* Varied perspectives on China

* *Weeks 3****–****4 Intellectual Foundations**

The sessions explore the systems of thoughts which have shaped the people, society and culture of China in history and remain influential today.

Week 3

* Confucianism: The Pre-Qin Era to the Han Dynasty
* Alternatives to Confucianism: Daoism between the Pre-Qin Era to the Northern and the Southern Dynasties
* Revival of Confucianism: Neo-Confucianism in the Song and Ming Dynasties and beyond

Week 4

* Reformist thoughts in the Late Qing period
* Challenges to tradition: The May Fourth Movement
* Marxism: its adaptation and continuing development in China

* *Weeks 5****–****6 Historical Epochs**

The sessions explore the major historical currents that motivated social transformations and institutional changes in China, as well as China’s encounters with other civilisations.

Week 5

* The pursuit of unification since the Qin Dynasty and the establishment of the unitary state
* The imperial examination system since the Sui Dynasty

Week 6

* Cultural encounters with other civilisations in Chinese history
* “The Century of Humiliation”: China’s responses to imperialist aggressions since the First Opium War

* *Weeks 7****–****8 Modernisation**

The sessions explore China’s progress towards modernisation and the emergence of its characteristic traits as a modern state as shown in defining periods from the mid-19th century onwards.

Week 7

* The late-Qing reforms: sources, consequences, and the awakening of the masses
* New Culture Movement: the emergence of the new vernacular Chinese language, avant-garde movements, mass culture movements, and its legacies today
* Institutional changes in the early Republican era

Week 8

* Concepts of “modernity” and “modernisation”, and their applicability to the case of China
* Globalisation and cultural China

* *Weeks 9****–****10 Economy**

The sessions explore some of the core characteristics of China’s economy.

Week 9

* Land, property and the agrarian society in traditional China
* Demographic characteristics of the Chinese population

Week 10

* Land reform, labour, and social mobility
* Development in infrastructures from the twentieth century onwards
* Historical interpretations of recent economic strategies: Open-up and Reform and Belt and Road Initiative
* Poverty alleviation
* Sustainable development and the construction of “ecological civilisation”

* *Weeks 11****–****12 Science and Technology**

The sessions explore the important achievements in science and technology in China’s past and present.

Week 11

* Major advances in science and technology from the Pre-Qin Era to the Song Dynasty
* The scientific inventions and thoughts introduced by Western missionaries in the Ming and Qing Dynasties
* Cross-cultural transmission of scientific concepts in China

Week 12

* The rise of scientific thinking and educational institution from the early 20th century onwards
* Institutionalisation of science after 1949
* Recent policies and initiatives to advance science and technology

* *Week 13 Connecting Tradition and Modernity in Understanding China**

The concluding session extends the course’s discussion with a focus on the connection between tradition and modernity with respect to the five themes.

* Manifestations of intellectual traditions in the present-day China
* China in the history of the world
* China in the post-modern era
* Prospects of China in economy and science and technology
* Global perspectives on China

courses.description: This course examines the relations between Chinese culture and literature, enabling students to gain a critical understanding of the cultural content in Chinese literary works as well as the cultural contexts in which literary developments took place. courses.title: China from Tradition to Modernity
courses.description: This course compares and contrasts traditional Chinese society and its modern development. In addition, it also seeks to understand and explain the transition between these two contrasting stages. The course will be organized along the line of the “from tradition to modernity” thesis, by way of which the institutional and cultural development in Chinese society can be re-examined in a comprehensive light, encompassing both their traditional formation and modern transformation.

4. Setting the foundation and backdrop for understanding events and development in China today.

5. Rethinking and reviewing the relevance of tradition in the modernization of Chinese society.

courses.subject: UGEA
courses.title: China's Cultural Heritage
courses.description:
(UGEA2330 is double-coded with ANTH2760.)

This course aims to give students a visual and integrated understanding of Chinese civilization and cultural development in mainland China through analysing China's material cultural heritage, mainly traditional villages, ancient cities and grottos, as well as ceramics, jade and bronze items. The course will discuss the ecological, economic and cultural meanings of the above cultural properties in China, examine the preservation, management and exploitation of cultural heritage, and analyse how China's heritage has been re-interpreted and reconstructed to suit current economic, social and political needs, including the development of tourism, and the construction of ethnicity, nationalism and Chinese identity.

Co-requisite: UGFH1000, UGFN1000 or UGFN1001 (only applicable to students admitted to the 4-year curriculum)
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should:

- Know the origin and development of Chinese culture from the past to the present, including the origin and development of Chinese civilization, social stratification, beliefs and lifestyles etc.

- have a comprehensive understanding of the concepts and theoretical issues related to Chinese material culture and heritage.

- learn to critically evaluate the significance and value of Chinese material culture.

- develop a multi-disciplinary awareness in pursuit of knowledge
courses.course_syllabus:
This course provides a holistic and integrated approach for students to understand China’s cultural heritage through items of material culture. Based on research from archaeology, cultural anthropology and other disciplines, the course focuses on several major aspects of material culture in China, as well as theoretical issues related to the impact and significance of Chinese material culture current Chinese society and individuals. After taking this course, students will have a basic understanding of the "roots" of modern Chinese culture and society, and how they are expressed in material culture. Students will also learn to critically evaluate Chinese material cultural heritage.

The core content of this course consists of the following:

Material culture and China's heritage: definitions.

Human settlements: from villages to cities in ancient China

Pottery, changing economics, and the origin of agriculture in China

Jade and the occurrence of complex society in China

Bronze items and the origin of Chinese civilization

Bronze items, social hierarchy and ancestor worship in China

The origin and development of ceramics in China

Ceramic figurines, burials and beliefs in historical China

Material cultural heritage and ethnicities in ancient and contemporary China

Material cultural heritage and its use in the construction of modem Chinese nationalism and identity.

The management of material cultural heritage in China and economic development

Selective topics of this courses are follows:

Materials cultural heritage as indicators of social conflicts in China

Material cultural heritage as evidence of political development in ancient China

courses.title: Culture and Modernity in China
courses.description:
(UGEA2332 is double-coded with ANTH2420.)

The remarkable economic emergence of China and Asia more broadly in recent decades has transformed many impoverished and largely agriculturally based societies into the most dynamic region of the contemporary world. China’s burgeoning aspirational middle classes, rapid urbanisation, time-space compression and the shift from command economies to de-regulated markets have had profound effects on people's everyday lives and the diverse cultural practices that have long shaped local livelihoods and community expectations. This course offers an introduction into anthropological approaches to the study of culture, modernity and globalisation in China and Asia more broadly. Relevant themes that have attracted anthropological interest include changing traditions and popular culture, adaptive custom and cosmopolitanism, migration and citizenship, identity politics and social movements as well as distinctive and emergent forms of governance in both collective and self-cultivating forms of expression. Drawing on a rich corpus of social theory and ethnographic research from anthropologists past and present, the course will provide students with conceptual and analytical tools to appreciate adaptive cultural practices in comparative terms, to review and appreciate the key anthropological debates and influential works in the study of modernity, and to introduce students to ethnographic approaches for researching and writing on modernity and contemporary ethnographies of global connection.

courses.title: China Today
courses.description: China is looming large on the global scene and our everyday life. It is a rising power that is changing the world order. It is a land of promising opportunities that attract an immense amount of capital and talents from overseas. Not to mention that a large part of the stuff we consume is produced in China. However, China is still—at least nominally—a socialist country that continues to embrace one-party rule and political censorship. Through the holistic perspective of anthropology that gives equal emphasis on political, economic, social, cultural, and ecological factors, this course addresses a host of issues that are salient in understanding China and its position in the contemporary world. The anthropological perspective is particularly good at making sense of the macro-level issues through studying day-to-day details and processes in a small locale. This course starts with examining China's revolution-packed modern history and the making of the powerful Communist Party; topics covered include classical anthropological themes on family, kinship, religion, education, ethnicity, identity, and morality. In the second half of the semester, this course examines emerging social concerns to explore how global processes such as modernization and late-capitalist development shape Chinese cultural and social institutions. These concerns include consumerism, individualism, urbanization, underground (unofficial) culture, civil society and activism, and financialization and digitalization. The course also draws from disciplines other than anthropology—for example, history—and some of the finest journalist writings on China. The overall intention is to provide a well-rounded and nuanced understanding of China today. The course prepares students for the United Nation’s Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Anthropology has a strong heritage concerning inequality, marginalized group, human and environment, and wellbeing for all. Analyzing China, this course aims at understanding the development and choices of human beings. Therefore, the course will improve students’ reflection on several SDGs including “promoting inclusive and sustainable economic growth,” “reducing inequality within and among countries,” “sustainable consumption and production patterns,” and “peaceful and inclusive societies for sustainable development and providing access to justice for all.”

courses.course_syllabus:
* *I. Introduction**

* *1. Introduction: China and the World**

Key: China is a an integrated part of the world, not an exotic other.

SDGs: choices and development for human beings

* *2. Diversity: History, Geography and Ethnicity**

Key1: Holistic understanding of China that considered the imapcts of geography, climate, history, economic life, and social institutions on cultures.

Key 2: Understanding the implication of the claim “China is a unified multi-ethnic country”

SDGs: poverty and ethnic inequality

* *3. Relatedness: Family, Kinship and Morality**

Key: Understanding traditional Chinese cosmology and therefore the importance of the family through an analysis of Fei Xiaotong’s Differential Mode of Association.

SGDs: culture, environment and social institution

* *4. Modernization: A One Hundred Year Quest**

Key: Why does being modern so attractive to the Chinese? Understanding historically the evolving meanings of modernity in the Chinese context.

SDGs: nation-building and marginality

* *II. Contemporary China**

* *5. *Dangguo*: The Party-State**

Key: Analyzing the ideology and practices of *dangguo*, the party-state, and how political institution shapes identity and daily practices.

SDGs: political institution and justice

* *6. Hierarchy: Class and Radical Individualism**

Key: Introducing the transition from collectivism to a market-oriented individualism and explain how extreme consumerism and the prioritzing of self-enterprising will result in an alienation from social well-being.

SDGs: historical contingency, sustainable consumption patterns

* *7. Divide: The Dying Village and Migration**

Key: Arguing how the *hukou,* household registration, system has resulted in a urban-rural divide and the pursuit of urbanization becomes an ideology that contribute to economic development at the expense of the environment and personal well-being.

SDGs: sustainable production, inclusive society, and wellbeing

* *8. Noise: Underground Music and Unofficial Culture**

Key: While the the various processes (consumerism, individualization, urbanization, etc.) has resulted in strict social formation of appropriate subjectivity, there are always rooms for negotiation and having different voices. This week we focus on music and other cultural production to deliver this argument.

SDGs: resillience and empowerment

* *9. Activism: Labor and Gender**

Key: In this week, we use up to date social events in either labor or gender related issues to examine how individuals exercise agency in existing structure and analyze whether actions could lead to effective changes. If not, why? We will also contemplate on what “public opinion” means in China.

SDGs: Inequality, decent work, and empowering women and girls

* *10. Environment: Development and the Nature**

Key: The ideology of development has been strongly a part of China’s political and economic legitimacy since the end of the 1970s. This week we explore how the nature and the environment are understood in these years.

SDGs: Responsible production and sustainable future

* *11. Digitalization: E-Commerce and Digital Governing**

Key: How have the fast development of e-commerce platforms and the employement of digital governing technologies – shape the society? This week we will use the concept of “the exemplary soceity” to analyze the various perception regarding digitalization.

SDGs: Inequality, effective institutions and sustainable economy

* *12. The Epidemic: Crisis and Humanity**

Key: The recent epidemic crisis shows how the world is highly connected and integrated and, on the other hand, reveals how class, racial and other boundaries are created in contexts. We will use the concept of “pandemic public” to facilitate arguments about China as an area studies.

SDGs: Healthcare and accountable institutions

* *III. Wrap Up**

* *13. China, Asia and The World**

Key: In the future, will China dominate the world as a superpower or facilitate cooperation as a leader? This week we will both look back in history to see what’s the relationship between China and the world before we have a strong idea of territorial boundary and also examine whether there be another China that focus on common values.

SDGs: Inclusive and sustainable future

courses.description:
(UGEA2433 is double-coded with CHES2107.)

Science and technology in China from antiquity to the present is surveyed through the study of selected topics in some depth. Particular emphasis is given to science and technology as a window to appreciate certain aspects of Chinese culture and history. Two important questions are explored through contrasting China with the West: the conditions for the development of modern science and the central role of science and technology in modernization.

Specific topics include the following: (1) history of science and technology in the West as background; (2) scientific thought and concepts of nature in ancient China; (3) traditional Chinese mathematics; (4) traditional Chinese astronomy; (5) Chinese medicine: history, philosophy, theory and practice; (6) innovation and progress in pre-modern Chinese technology; (7) early introduction of western science by missionaries and the Needham question; (8) science and technology in the Self-Strengthening Movement and the May Fourth Movement (‘Mr Science’); (9) science and technology from 1949 to the 1980s; (10) innovation and technology since the 1980s.

courses.learning_outcomes: After taking the course, students should have gained, through an acquaintance with the history of science and technology in China, one perspective of Chinese culture and history. Through contrasting China with the West, students should have been challenged to reflect upon the conditions for the development of science in any society, and the central role of science and technology in modernization -- including modernization as a key narrative of Chinese history from the mid-19th century to the present.

courses.description: Chinese novels have long been intertwined with religious culture. The Confucian, Buddhist and Daoist thoughts permeate classical Chinese novels. As a lively epitome of Chinese religious culture, these novels also promoted the spread of religious thoughts among the people. This course aims to investigate the interactive relationship between Chinese novels and religion. Students will be guided to examine the religious contents in novels and the ways in which religious thoughts shape the motifs, characterization, language and narrative structure of the novels. Texts selected for reading include masterpieces of Chinese novels, such as The Story of the Stone, The Journey to the West, The Investiture of the Gods and Strange Tales of Liaozhai.
